attributes.title: Can Bad Be Good? The Attraction of a Darker Self
attributes.description:
Generally, people shy away from similar others with undesirable qualities. We show that when those others are fictional, the opposite occurs. People are drawn toward villains who seem similar to themselves.

The data for all five experiments listed in the paper are presented here.

summary.value: This registration contains the data for Studies 4, 5, and 6 associated with this project, as well as code for reproducing the analyses in the published paper.

registration_responses.summary: This registration contains the data for Studies 4, 5, and 6 associated with this project, as well as code for reproducing the analyses in the published paper.

attributes.title: Evidence of integrated primary-secondary health care in  low-and middle-income countries: protocol for a scoping review
attributes.description:
Integrated care is a people-centered health delivery approach that ensures the comprehensiveness, quality, and continuity of service across the settings and levels of health systems. The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends integration across levels and building-blocks of health systems as a prerequisite of Universal Health Coverage (UHC). While health systems of low and middle-income countries (LMICs) are often fragmented and led by siloed service delivery structure, several LMICs – including India – have attempted health system integration. Several systematic reviews of evidence on healthcare integration from developed countries exist, but to date, no synthesis from LMICs was reported. This review will provide an overview of existing Integrated Primary Secondary Care Systems (IPSCS) in the context of LMICs, aiming to support policy decisions for the effective integration of health delivery systems in India. 

The review will be conducted following the six steps recommend by Arksey and O’Malley. Scientific and grey literature will be systematically selected from PubMed, Embase, Scopus, Web of Science, Global Index Medicus, and electronic repositories of the WHO, World Bank, Health Policy Plus and OpenGrey. Using a comprehensive search strategy, literature written in English and published between 2000-2019 will be selected, and two independent authors will screen their titles and abstracts. The result will be charted using a data extraction form and reported using tables, figures, and in narrative form. 

No ethical approval is necessary for the review. The review will be conducted between December 2019 and April 2020. The final report will be developed with the consultation of other stakeholders and disseminated through workshops, conference papers, and peer review articles. The review will serve as a guiding tool to approach, implement, and test the IPSCS model in India and other LMICs.

q2.value: Md Zabir Hasan, Shalini Singh, Dinesh Arora, Nishant Jain, Shivam Gupta

Not applicable

To conduct the scoping review, we will consider the six stages recommended by Arksey and O’Malley. The stages include - (1) identifying the research questions, (2) identifying relevant literature, (3) selecting studies based on a specific inclusion and exclusion criteria, (4) charting the data, (5) collating and reporting the results, and (6) expert consultation and writing the report. 

The result will be charted using a data extraction form and reported using tables, figures, and in narrative form. Synthesis of the IPSCS evidence from LMICs will be clustered and presented to explore the geographic, socioeconomic, and health system variation across the countries. However, it is essential to emphasize that during the review process, we will not assess the quality of the evidence, compare the robustness or generalizability of different IPSCS models

q25.value: Ethical approval will not be necessary for the scoping review. The required information will be obtained from the publicly available literature on integrated health care models that have been adopted in LMICs, and no primary data will be collected. This scoping review forms a part of the overarching study to-explore the scope of IPSCS under AB Program in India. The findings of this review will be finalized after a consultation exercise with other researchers and organizational networks, practitioners, and public health policymakers to enhance the quality of the review. The final report will be disseminated through a workshop involving key national and state-level stakeholders for AB in India. The findings of the review will serve as an advocacy tool for rolling out IPSCS for UHC in India.

attributes.title: Gender Stereotypes About STEM Abilities Meta-Analysis
attributes.description: This synthesis project aims to bring clarity to the mixed findings on (a) how gender stereotypes about STEM and verbal abilities first develop (Meta-Analysis 1) and (b) how they relate to gender gaps in STEM (Meta-Analysis 2).

q1.value: The Development of Gender Stereotypes About STEM and Verbal Abilities: A Preregistered Meta-Analysis

q3.value:
This synthesis project aims to bring clarity to the mixed findings on (a) how gender stereotypes about STEM and verbal abilities first develop (Meta-Analysis 1) and (b) how they relate to gender gaps in STEM (Meta-Analysis 2). Though both meta-analyses will examine STEM and verbal ability stereotypes, the second meta-analysis will focus on just STEM outcomes (i.e., relating STEM and verbal stereotypes to STEM outcomes, but not verbal stereotypes to verbal outcomes, for which there is likely limited research). We plan to present the two meta-analyses as two separate journal articles, though this preregistration includes our plans for both. Both meta-analyses will be restricted to samples of children and adolescents (age < 18 years).

The answers to the following structured OSF questions provide a high-level summary of our preregistered plans, but the uploaded protocol document provides much more detail.

q4.value:
Pages 6-8 of the uploaded protocol document provide a graphical representation and table of our core directional hypotheses (see Figure 2, Figure 3, and Table 1), which we summarize here.

For Meta-Analysis 1, we predict that *pro-male STEM* ability stereotypes will be stronger for:

1. Older than younger children
2. Male than female child participants
3. White than Black, non-Hispanic child participants (U.S. only)
4. Earlier than later data collection years (U.S. only)
5. Nations with a lower representation of women among STEM majors
6. Nations with a lower representation of women among employed researchers
7. Indirect than direct stereotype measures
8. Adult than child stereotype targets

We also predict that *pro-female verbal* ability stereotypes will be stronger for: 

9. Older than younger children
10. Female than male child participants

We also predict the following:

11. Negative Age × Male Participant interaction for pro-male STEM stereotypes (see Figure 2)
12. Positive Age × Male Participant interaction for pro-female verbal stereotypes (see Figure 2)
13. Stronger magnitude for pro-female verbal stereotypes than pro-male STEM stereotype

We will consider the three variables of children’s age, children gender, and stereotype domain (STEM vs. verbal) to be of greatest theoretical importance for Meta-Analysis 1, though we will also view the moderators for Hypotheses 3-8 (listed above) as confirmatory. (Exploratory analyses will examine other moderators that we will code for such as STEM domain, but they will be reported as exploratory because of likely data limitations or the lack of strong directional predictions based on relevant psychological theory).

Meta-Analysis 2 will focus on four categories of correlations (i.e., how STEM and verbal stereotypes relate to STEM motivational outcomes, separately for boys and girls). We predict the following for the direction of these stereotype-outcome correlations (see Figure 3):

14. Negative for girls’ pro-male STEM stereotypes
15. Positive for boys pro-male STEM stereotypes
16. Negative for girls’ pro-female verbal stereotypes
17. Positive for boys’ pro-female verbal stereotypes

For the correlations for girls’ pro-male STEM stereotypes, we also predict those correlations will be stronger in magnitude (i.e., larger negative values) for: 

18. Older than younger children 
19. Indirect than direct stereotype measures 
20. Stereotype measures with child than adult targets 
21. Confidence than other outcomes

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This project consists of two meta-analyses that will analyze variation in (a) mean levels of children’s gender stereotypes about STEM and verbal abilities and (b) these stereotypes’ correlations with motivational STEM outcomes such as confidence and interests. In both meta-analyses, focal moderators will include child demographics, cultural contexts, and measurement characteristics. The uploaded protocol document describes our study design in detail.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value:
Our preliminary searches (i.e., a “scoping” review) examined citations to highly influential papers (e.g., Ambady, Shih, Kim, & Pittinsky, 2001) and found 58 potentially eligible studies with more than 25,000 children, demonstrating a voluminous literature. Some studies of children have found the expected stereotype of superior male ability in mathematics and science (e.g., Hargreaves, Homer, & Swinnerton, 2008), but others have found only in-group bias (e.g., Heyman & Legare, 2004) or even stereotypes of female superiority (e.g., Rowley, Kurtz-Costes, Mistry, & Feagans, 2007). The evidence is also mixed on how these stereotypes relate to gender gaps in motivational outcomes, such as confidence, interests, and future career plans in STEM (e.g., Evans, Copping, Rowley, & Kurtz-Costes, 2011). Several aspects of this scoping review informed the development of our review protocol (e.g., we used common phrases in the abstracts to develop our tentative list of keywords for the literature search). However, at the time of preregistration, we have not completed our formal screening process or coded studies. We have nearly finished our initial abstract screening but have not yet started full text screening.

The PI analyzed a small subset of studies on children’s ability stereotypes (14 studies) more than six years ago in July 2013 but has not since reanalyzed those data (e.g., the PI did not reanalyze the data to prepare this protocol). This cursory analysis examined three moderators (gender, age, and stereotype domain for math vs. verbal). Some results were consistent with our current hypotheses (i.e., stronger pro-female verbal than pro-male math stereotypes, in-group preferences that declined with age), but other results were not consistent (i.e., no main effect of age). We still predict a main effect of age based on developmental theory and a related published meta-analysis (Miller, Nolla, Eagly, & Uttal, 2018), even though the earlier analysis of ability stereotype did not find such an effect. We consider our current protocol to be a preregistration because it greatly differs from this prior analysis both in terms of scope and approach. For example, in contrast to the 14 studies included in the earlier analysis, we expect to code and analyze roughly 80 to 120 studies for this project.

question.value:
The uploaded protocol document detail our search strategy (pages 9–12 and Appendix A), inclusion criteria (pages 12 – 13), and screening procedures (page 14 and Appendix B), which we summarize below.

SEARCH STRATEGY: We will gather citations to potentially relevant studies using (a) keyword searches of literature datasets, (b) grey literature searches, (c) citation tracking, and (d) emails to study authors. Each search strategy includes systematic methods for finding unpublished studies, such as using ProQuest to identify doctoral dissertations in Strategy 1. Finding grey literature is critical because reviews can otherwise produce distorted conclusions by focusing on well-known, easily available, published studies. Our four-pronged, multidisciplinary search process will help mitigate such biases.

INCLUSION CRITERIA: We will include studies that (a) included a sample of children (age < 18 years), (b) measured gender stereotypes about STEM or verbal abilities, (c) included a stereotype measure whose response structure permits directional assessment of stereotypes, (d) included at least 10 total child participants, (e) measured stereotypes before an experimental manipulation, (f) separately reported statistics for ability-related stereotype items (or at least 50% of a scale’s items were ability-related), and (g) reported sufficient quantitative information to compute effect sizes. Meta-Analysis 2 will include the subset of studies that reported how STEM ability stereotypes correlated with at least one eligible motivational STEM outcome (i.e., confidence, interests and values, or future educational and career plans in STEM) or STEM performance outcome (i.e., test scores or grades). Eligible studies must report these stereotype-outcome correlations disaggregated by children’s gender (or for only one gender group).

SCREENING PROCESS: Using the above inclusion criteria, we will screen citations in three stages (see Appendix B for our preliminary screening manual). In Stage 1 (abstract review), screeners will examine titles and abstracts using the screening tool Abstrackr to help facilitate and manage this initial review (Rathbone, Hoffmann, & Glasziou, 2015); screeners will exclude only obviously ineligible articles at this stage. In Stage 2 (full text review), screeners will thoroughly examine the full text, including only articles meeting all the inclusion criteria. In Stage 3 (data review), we will contact study authors for missing information needed to compute effect sizes and then exclude studies in which no effect sizes can be computed, even after sending author queries. We separate Stages 2 and 3 to track otherwise eligible studies lacking needed effect size data (i.e., we will keep a list of such studies). In practice, Stage 3 will be combined with study coding; before coding a study, the coder will first determine whether effect sizes can be extracted and flag studies for author query as needed.

q13.value: Our initial scoping review found 58 potentially eligible studies. Because our four-pronged systematic search process will likely find many more eligible studies, we expect to code approximately 80–120 primary studies. Studies from our scoping review generally had substantial sample sizes (average N = 481), which means our analyses likely will be well powered to detect even small effects. Using Hedges and Pigott’s (2001) formulas and assuming 80 studies with N = 481, we estimate there would be sufficient power (i.e., 80% power) to detect a minimum mean effect size of 0.07 assuming moderate study heterogeneity (tau = 0.2; I^2 = 95%) and 0.10 for large heterogeneity (tau = 0.3; I^2 = 98%).

q14.value: We will include all eligible studies that we find through search processes, regardless of the final number of studies to analyze.

q15.value: After completing our initial literature search and screening, we plan to update the literature search before submitting our first research manuscript, but we do not plan further updates after the first time of submitting the manuscript for peer review.

question.value: N/A

Trained coders will record the quantitative information needed to compute effect sizes (e.g., sample sizes, means) and code three categories of moderators: demographic, contextual, and measurement (see pages 15–16 and Appendix C in the uploaded protocol document).

META-ANALYSIS 1: The primary effect size metric for Meta-Analysis 1 will be mean levels of ability stereotypes, after transforming the original stereotype scales (e.g., 1–5 range) onto a common scale ranging from -1 to 1. Positive values will indicate conventional stereotypes (favoring male STEM ability or female verbal ability), and a value of 1 will indicate the maximum possible stereotype mean in that direction (e.g., for STEM stereotypes, all children selected the most extreme pro-male endpoint). For instance, a value of +0.35 would indicate 35% of the maximum possible pro-male STEM stereotype. Pages 16–18 of the uploaded protocol document detail three other effect size metrics (log transform, standardized means, and standard deviations) that we will examine in supplemental or sensitivity analyses.

META-ANALYSIS 2: Meta-Analysis 2 will focus on the correlations between STEM and verbal ability stereotypes with three focal categories of STEM motivational outcomes: (a) confidence (e.g., expectancies for success, self-efficacy, perceived ability), (b) interests and values (e.g., intrinsic value, enjoyment, utility value), and (c) future educational and career plans (e.g., intended college major). We will convert bivariate correlation coefficients (e.g., Pearson’s r) into Fisher’s z-scores for meta-analytic models. 

If multiple regression coefficients are reported instead, we will send an author query for the bivariate correlations. Though we currently do not plan to include partial correlations or regression coefficients in our analyses, we may decide to include them if we would lose too many studies (e.g., more than half) if we excluded them. We plan to make this decision after coding studies, but before analyzing the data, so that our decision is based on data availability, but not the results. If we do include partial correlations (e.g., converted from regression coefficients), we would include a dummy code for them in all moderator analyses. In addition, we would conduct sensitivity analyses to examine if any results depend on including this other category of correlations.

Pages 19–24 of the uploaded protocol document detail our analytic plan for both meta-analyses, which we summarize below. 

MODELS: We will use mixed-effects meta-regression models to investigate how stereotypes and their correlation with STEM outcomes vary across child demographics, cultural contexts, and measures. These models, which will be estimated using restricted maximum likelihood, will assume that variation in effect sizes is due to fixed effects of moderators (e.g., age), random effects of residual between-study heterogeneity, and within-study sampling variance (Borenstein et al., 2009). Because many studies likely will generate multiple effect sizes, we will implement robust variance estimation (RVE) to account for effect size dependencies, using the small-sample correction based on the Satterthwaite approximation (Tipton, 2015) and the “CR2” bias-reduced linearization adjustment (Pustejovky & Tipton, 2018). We will first estimate mixed-effects meta-analysis model parameters using the rma.mv() function in the metafor R package (Viechtbauer, 2010) and then adjust the standard errors, degrees of freedom, and p values by implementing RVE using the coef_test() function in the clubSandwich package (Pustejovsky, 2018). 

META-ANALYSIS 1: Confirmatory moderator analyses will test our directional hypotheses such as pro-male STEM ability stereotypes should strengthen with age. We will examine each moderator in separate models and in one multivariable model that will simultaneously adjust for all confirmatory moderators. To control for nuisance methods variance, all models will include four dummy-coded covariates for the scale type: (a) 2 or 3 response options, (b) forced-choice scale with no gender-neutral response option for individual items, (c) continuous scale (vs. discrete ratings), and (d) separate ratings (vs. comparative scales). Though effect sizes will be standardized, the original measurement scale still could contribute additional variance that should be adjusted for. STEM ability and verbal ability stereotypes will be analyzed in separate statistical models, except when directing comparing their overall magnitude (in that case, both will be included in the same model to account for their correlation).

META-ANALYSIS 2: Our core prediction for Meta-Analysis 2 is that pro-male STEM and pro-male female ability stereotypes should relate to motivational STEM outcomes negatively for girls and positively for boys. We will test these basic predictions with four separate random-effects models for the four broad categories of correlations (see Table 9), along with characterizing their overall heterogeneity. Two additional mixed-effects models (bottom rows of Table 9) will directly examine average differences between boys’ and girls’ correlations by including one moderator for gender. For the correlations between girls’ STEM ability stereotypes and STEM motivational outcomes, we will conduct additional moderator analyses using mixed-effects models. We focus on this category of correlations in part because we expect to obtain the most primary data for it (relative to other categories).

SELECTIVE REPORTING BIAS ANALYSES: Though we will use several systematic search methods to find unpublished studies, our conclusions may nevertheless be subject to selective reporting bias (e.g., publication bias or outcome reporting bias). Researchers may be cautious to report results conflicting with commonly accepted theory and research hypotheses. As detailed in Appendix D in the uploaded protocol document, we will use three approaches as sensitivity analyses to diagnose and adjust for such biases: (a) selection modeling, (b) comparison of unpublished versus published studies, and (c) meta-regression to assess small-study effects. If the three approaches yield diverging conclusions, we will place the greatest weight on selection models for reasons detailed in Appendix D. Simulation studies have shown superior performance for selection models, compared to other publication bias methods, in several conditions that may likely characterize our meta-analysis such as moderate to large between-study heterogeneity (Carter, Schönbrodt, Gervais, & Hilgard, 2019).

q20.value:
Whenever possible, we will record both the average and range for children’s age and grade level; children’s average age will be the focal moderator in analyses. If a study reports an age range but not average age, we will impute children’s age as the midpoint of the range (e.g., “four- and five-year-olds” would be coded as 5.0 years; “four-year-olds” would be 4.5 years). If the grade level but not age is reported, we will add 5.5 years to the grade level for U.S. samples (e.g., “third graders” would be 8.5 years) and adjust this transformation as necessary for nations with different grade bands (e.g., “Year 3” would be 9.5 years for U.K. samples). We will attempt to contact study authors for these details if neither age nor grade level information was reported. 

Publication status will differentiate between (a) articles in academic journals and edited books versus (b) dissertations, Master’s theses, conference papers, blog posts, and unpublished manuscripts. If a dissertation or other unpublished report was later published in a journal or edited book, we will consider that study to be published.

If any moderator level has 4 effect sizes or less, we will combine that moderator level with others prior to analysis (e.g., group engineering and computer science stereotypes measures as one category if there are not enough effects for disaggregated analysis of them), if possible.

q21.value:
We will determine two-tailed p-values for regression coefficients using t-tests based the Satterthwaite degrees of freedom and apply a default alpha cut-off level of .05 when determining statistical significance. However, we will lower the alpha level to .025 when the degrees of freedom for individual coefficients are less than 4 because of inflated Type I error rates in those scenarios (Tipton, 2015). In addition, if any moderator level has 4 effect sizes or less, we will combine that moderator level with others prior to analysis (e.g., group engineering and computer science stereotypes measures as one category if there are not enough effects for disaggregated analysis of them), if possible.

Because we have prespecified our confirmatory moderator analyses, we will not apply corrections for multiple comparisons to them. However, for exploratory analyses of potentially many more comparisons, we will use the Benjamini-Hochberg correction (Benjamini & Hochberg, 1995) to control false discovery rates, rather than the Bonferroni method which can too stringent in many situations (see Appendix F in What Works Clearinghouse, 2017).

q22.value: We will test the robustness of our findings to potential outliers by using the rstudent() function in the metafor package to identify effect sizes that have studentized deleted residuals exceeding 2.5 standard errors (Viechtbauer & Cheung, 2010). We will rerun meta-analytic models with and without such outliers, reporting when the conclusions are sensitive to such exclusions.

q23.value: We will use multiple imputation to account for any missing moderator data (e.g., for racial/ethnic composition) that may remain missing even after attempting to contact study authors. Compared to common listwise deletion practices, multiple imputation preserves a larger set of studies and can often produce less biased estimates (Pigott, 2001, 2012). We will implement a joint modelling approach by using the jomo R package to also account for the multilevel structure of the data (i.e., nesting within studies) when imputing moderator values (Quartagno, Grund, & Carpenter, in press). We will allow the level-1 covariance structures to randomly vary across studies by setting the “meth” option in the jomo() function equal to “random.” As a simplifying assumption, the imputation model will account for just the overall 2-level nesting structure (i.e., effects within studies). The effect sizes, but not their variances, will be included in the imputation models because omitting the outcome (i.e., effect sizes) when imputing covariates (i.e., moderators) can introduce bias due to a lack of correspondence between the imputation model and analysis model (e.g., Moons, Donders, Stijnen, & Harrell, 2006).

q24.value:
META-ANALYSIS 1: Exploratory analyses will examine additional moderators such as question wording and stereotype domain (e.g., math vs. spatial ability; Table 2) that may yield further insight. We also will explore interactions with age to advance understanding of possible developmental mechanisms (e.g., indirect and direct measures might show different age-related trends, especially if they capture distinct theoretical constructs). Last, we will repeat analyses separated by children’s gender to see if stereotypes vary in consistent ways for boys and girls. These analyses could help build fundamental theory about stereotype development and suggest promising novel directions for future research. However, we will interpret these exploratory analyses cautiously, given possible inflation of false-positive error rates.

META-ANALYSIS 2: Exploratory analyses will extend moderator analyses to the other effect size categories (e.g., correlations for boys), though the statistical power may be lower. We also will explore other moderators (e.g., socioeconomic status, stereotype or outcome STEM domain) and correlations with two categories of performance outcomes (i.e., test scores, grades).

q25.value: Answers to these structured OSF questions provide a high-level summary of our preregistered plans, but the uploaded protocol document provides much more detail.

registration_responses.q1: The Development of Gender Stereotypes About STEM and Verbal Abilities: A Preregistered Meta-Analysis
registration_responses.q3:
This synthesis project aims to bring clarity to the mixed findings on (a) how gender stereotypes about STEM and verbal abilities first develop (Meta-Analysis 1) and (b) how they relate to gender gaps in STEM (Meta-Analysis 2). Though both meta-analyses will examine STEM and verbal ability stereotypes, the second meta-analysis will focus on just STEM outcomes (i.e., relating STEM and verbal stereotypes to STEM outcomes, but not verbal stereotypes to verbal outcomes, for which there is likely limited research). We plan to present the two meta-analyses as two separate journal articles, though this preregistration includes our plans for both. Both meta-analyses will be restricted to samples of children and adolescents (age < 18 years).

The answers to the following structured OSF questions provide a high-level summary of our preregistered plans, but the uploaded protocol document provides much more detail.
registration_responses.q4:
Pages 6-8 of the uploaded protocol document provide a graphical representation and table of our core directional hypotheses (see Figure 2, Figure 3, and Table 1), which we summarize here.

For Meta-Analysis 1, we predict that *pro-male STEM* ability stereotypes will be stronger for:

1. Older than younger children
2. Male than female child participants
3. White than Black, non-Hispanic child participants (U.S. only)
4. Earlier than later data collection years (U.S. only)
5. Nations with a lower representation of women among STEM majors
6. Nations with a lower representation of women among employed researchers
7. Indirect than direct stereotype measures
8. Adult than child stereotype targets

We also predict that *pro-female verbal* ability stereotypes will be stronger for: 

9. Older than younger children
10. Female than male child participants

We also predict the following:

11. Negative Age × Male Participant interaction for pro-male STEM stereotypes (see Figure 2)
12. Positive Age × Male Participant interaction for pro-female verbal stereotypes (see Figure 2)
13. Stronger magnitude for pro-female verbal stereotypes than pro-male STEM stereotype

We will consider the three variables of children’s age, children gender, and stereotype domain (STEM vs. verbal) to be of greatest theoretical importance for Meta-Analysis 1, though we will also view the moderators for Hypotheses 3-8 (listed above) as confirmatory. (Exploratory analyses will examine other moderators that we will code for such as STEM domain, but they will be reported as exploratory because of likely data limitations or the lack of strong directional predictions based on relevant psychological theory).

Meta-Analysis 2 will focus on four categories of correlations (i.e., how STEM and verbal stereotypes relate to STEM motivational outcomes, separately for boys and girls). We predict the following for the direction of these stereotype-outcome correlations (see Figure 3):

14. Negative for girls’ pro-male STEM stereotypes
15. Positive for boys pro-male STEM stereotypes
16. Negative for girls’ pro-female verbal stereotypes
17. Positive for boys’ pro-female verbal stereotypes

For the correlations for girls’ pro-male STEM stereotypes, we also predict those correlations will be stronger in magnitude (i.e., larger negative values) for: 

18. Older than younger children 
19. Indirect than direct stereotype measures 
20. Stereotype measures with child than adult targets 
21. Confidence than other outcomes
registration_responses.q5: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q11:
Our preliminary searches (i.e., a “scoping” review) examined citations to highly influential papers (e.g., Ambady, Shih, Kim, & Pittinsky, 2001) and found 58 potentially eligible studies with more than 25,000 children, demonstrating a voluminous literature. Some studies of children have found the expected stereotype of superior male ability in mathematics and science (e.g., Hargreaves, Homer, & Swinnerton, 2008), but others have found only in-group bias (e.g., Heyman & Legare, 2004) or even stereotypes of female superiority (e.g., Rowley, Kurtz-Costes, Mistry, & Feagans, 2007). The evidence is also mixed on how these stereotypes relate to gender gaps in motivational outcomes, such as confidence, interests, and future career plans in STEM (e.g., Evans, Copping, Rowley, & Kurtz-Costes, 2011). Several aspects of this scoping review informed the development of our review protocol (e.g., we used common phrases in the abstracts to develop our tentative list of keywords for the literature search). However, at the time of preregistration, we have not completed our formal screening process or coded studies. We have nearly finished our initial abstract screening but have not yet started full text screening.

The PI analyzed a small subset of studies on children’s ability stereotypes (14 studies) more than six years ago in July 2013 but has not since reanalyzed those data (e.g., the PI did not reanalyze the data to prepare this protocol). This cursory analysis examined three moderators (gender, age, and stereotype domain for math vs. verbal). Some results were consistent with our current hypotheses (i.e., stronger pro-female verbal than pro-male math stereotypes, in-group preferences that declined with age), but other results were not consistent (i.e., no main effect of age). We still predict a main effect of age based on developmental theory and a related published meta-analysis (Miller, Nolla, Eagly, & Uttal, 2018), even though the earlier analysis of ability stereotype did not find such an effect. We consider our current protocol to be a preregistration because it greatly differs from this prior analysis both in terms of scope and approach. For example, in contrast to the 14 studies included in the earlier analysis, we expect to code and analyze roughly 80 to 120 studies for this project.
registration_responses.q13: Our initial scoping review found 58 potentially eligible studies. Because our four-pronged systematic search process will likely find many more eligible studies, we expect to code approximately 80–120 primary studies. Studies from our scoping review generally had substantial sample sizes (average N = 481), which means our analyses likely will be well powered to detect even small effects. Using Hedges and Pigott’s (2001) formulas and assuming 80 studies with N = 481, we estimate there would be sufficient power (i.e., 80% power) to detect a minimum mean effect size of 0.07 assuming moderate study heterogeneity (tau = 0.2; I^2 = 95%) and 0.10 for large heterogeneity (tau = 0.3; I^2 = 98%).
registration_responses.q14: We will include all eligible studies that we find through search processes, regardless of the final number of studies to analyze.
registration_responses.q15: After completing our initial literature search and screening, we plan to update the literature search before submitting our first research manuscript, but we do not plan further updates after the first time of submitting the manuscript for peer review.
registration_responses.q20:
Whenever possible, we will record both the average and range for children’s age and grade level; children’s average age will be the focal moderator in analyses. If a study reports an age range but not average age, we will impute children’s age as the midpoint of the range (e.g., “four- and five-year-olds” would be coded as 5.0 years; “four-year-olds” would be 4.5 years). If the grade level but not age is reported, we will add 5.5 years to the grade level for U.S. samples (e.g., “third graders” would be 8.5 years) and adjust this transformation as necessary for nations with different grade bands (e.g., “Year 3” would be 9.5 years for U.K. samples). We will attempt to contact study authors for these details if neither age nor grade level information was reported. 

Publication status will differentiate between (a) articles in academic journals and edited books versus (b) dissertations, Master’s theses, conference papers, blog posts, and unpublished manuscripts. If a dissertation or other unpublished report was later published in a journal or edited book, we will consider that study to be published.

If any moderator level has 4 effect sizes or less, we will combine that moderator level with others prior to analysis (e.g., group engineering and computer science stereotypes measures as one category if there are not enough effects for disaggregated analysis of them), if possible.
registration_responses.q21:
We will determine two-tailed p-values for regression coefficients using t-tests based the Satterthwaite degrees of freedom and apply a default alpha cut-off level of .05 when determining statistical significance. However, we will lower the alpha level to .025 when the degrees of freedom for individual coefficients are less than 4 because of inflated Type I error rates in those scenarios (Tipton, 2015). In addition, if any moderator level has 4 effect sizes or less, we will combine that moderator level with others prior to analysis (e.g., group engineering and computer science stereotypes measures as one category if there are not enough effects for disaggregated analysis of them), if possible.

Because we have prespecified our confirmatory moderator analyses, we will not apply corrections for multiple comparisons to them. However, for exploratory analyses of potentially many more comparisons, we will use the Benjamini-Hochberg correction (Benjamini & Hochberg, 1995) to control false discovery rates, rather than the Bonferroni method which can too stringent in many situations (see Appendix F in What Works Clearinghouse, 2017).
registration_responses.q22: We will test the robustness of our findings to potential outliers by using the rstudent() function in the metafor package to identify effect sizes that have studentized deleted residuals exceeding 2.5 standard errors (Viechtbauer & Cheung, 2010). We will rerun meta-analytic models with and without such outliers, reporting when the conclusions are sensitive to such exclusions.
registration_responses.q23: We will use multiple imputation to account for any missing moderator data (e.g., for racial/ethnic composition) that may remain missing even after attempting to contact study authors. Compared to common listwise deletion practices, multiple imputation preserves a larger set of studies and can often produce less biased estimates (Pigott, 2001, 2012). We will implement a joint modelling approach by using the jomo R package to also account for the multilevel structure of the data (i.e., nesting within studies) when imputing moderator values (Quartagno, Grund, & Carpenter, in press). We will allow the level-1 covariance structures to randomly vary across studies by setting the “meth” option in the jomo() function equal to “random.” As a simplifying assumption, the imputation model will account for just the overall 2-level nesting structure (i.e., effects within studies). The effect sizes, but not their variances, will be included in the imputation models because omitting the outcome (i.e., effect sizes) when imputing covariates (i.e., moderators) can introduce bias due to a lack of correspondence between the imputation model and analysis model (e.g., Moons, Donders, Stijnen, & Harrell, 2006).
registration_responses.q24:
META-ANALYSIS 1: Exploratory analyses will examine additional moderators such as question wording and stereotype domain (e.g., math vs. spatial ability; Table 2) that may yield further insight. We also will explore interactions with age to advance understanding of possible developmental mechanisms (e.g., indirect and direct measures might show different age-related trends, especially if they capture distinct theoretical constructs). Last, we will repeat analyses separated by children’s gender to see if stereotypes vary in consistent ways for boys and girls. These analyses could help build fundamental theory about stereotype development and suggest promising novel directions for future research. However, we will interpret these exploratory analyses cautiously, given possible inflation of false-positive error rates.

META-ANALYSIS 2: Exploratory analyses will extend moderator analyses to the other effect size categories (e.g., correlations for boys), though the statistical power may be lower. We also will explore other moderators (e.g., socioeconomic status, stereotype or outcome STEM domain) and correlations with two categories of performance outcomes (i.e., test scores, grades).
registration_responses.q25: Answers to these structured OSF questions provide a high-level summary of our preregistered plans, but the uploaded protocol document provides much more detail.
registration_responses.q8.question: This project consists of two meta-analyses that will analyze variation in (a) mean levels of children’s gender stereotypes about STEM and verbal abilities and (b) these stereotypes’ correlations with motivational STEM outcomes such as confidence and interests. In both meta-analyses, focal moderators will include child demographics, cultural contexts, and measurement characteristics. The uploaded protocol document describes our study design in detail.
registration_responses.q12.question:
The uploaded protocol document detail our search strategy (pages 9–12 and Appendix A), inclusion criteria (pages 12 – 13), and screening procedures (page 14 and Appendix B), which we summarize below.

SEARCH STRATEGY: We will gather citations to potentially relevant studies using (a) keyword searches of literature datasets, (b) grey literature searches, (c) citation tracking, and (d) emails to study authors. Each search strategy includes systematic methods for finding unpublished studies, such as using ProQuest to identify doctoral dissertations in Strategy 1. Finding grey literature is critical because reviews can otherwise produce distorted conclusions by focusing on well-known, easily available, published studies. Our four-pronged, multidisciplinary search process will help mitigate such biases.

INCLUSION CRITERIA: We will include studies that (a) included a sample of children (age < 18 years), (b) measured gender stereotypes about STEM or verbal abilities, (c) included a stereotype measure whose response structure permits directional assessment of stereotypes, (d) included at least 10 total child participants, (e) measured stereotypes before an experimental manipulation, (f) separately reported statistics for ability-related stereotype items (or at least 50% of a scale’s items were ability-related), and (g) reported sufficient quantitative information to compute effect sizes. Meta-Analysis 2 will include the subset of studies that reported how STEM ability stereotypes correlated with at least one eligible motivational STEM outcome (i.e., confidence, interests and values, or future educational and career plans in STEM) or STEM performance outcome (i.e., test scores or grades). Eligible studies must report these stereotype-outcome correlations disaggregated by children’s gender (or for only one gender group).

SCREENING PROCESS: Using the above inclusion criteria, we will screen citations in three stages (see Appendix B for our preliminary screening manual). In Stage 1 (abstract review), screeners will examine titles and abstracts using the screening tool Abstrackr to help facilitate and manage this initial review (Rathbone, Hoffmann, & Glasziou, 2015); screeners will exclude only obviously ineligible articles at this stage. In Stage 2 (full text review), screeners will thoroughly examine the full text, including only articles meeting all the inclusion criteria. In Stage 3 (data review), we will contact study authors for missing information needed to compute effect sizes and then exclude studies in which no effect sizes can be computed, even after sending author queries. We separate Stages 2 and 3 to track otherwise eligible studies lacking needed effect size data (i.e., we will keep a list of such studies). In practice, Stage 3 will be combined with study coding; before coding a study, the coder will first determine whether effect sizes can be extracted and flag studies for author query as needed.
registration_responses.q16.question: N/A
registration_responses.q17.question: Trained coders will record the quantitative information needed to compute effect sizes (e.g., sample sizes, means) and code three categories of moderators: demographic, contextual, and measurement (see pages 15–16 and Appendix C in the uploaded protocol document).
registration_responses.q18.question:
META-ANALYSIS 1: The primary effect size metric for Meta-Analysis 1 will be mean levels of ability stereotypes, after transforming the original stereotype scales (e.g., 1–5 range) onto a common scale ranging from -1 to 1. Positive values will indicate conventional stereotypes (favoring male STEM ability or female verbal ability), and a value of 1 will indicate the maximum possible stereotype mean in that direction (e.g., for STEM stereotypes, all children selected the most extreme pro-male endpoint). For instance, a value of +0.35 would indicate 35% of the maximum possible pro-male STEM stereotype. Pages 16–18 of the uploaded protocol document detail three other effect size metrics (log transform, standardized means, and standard deviations) that we will examine in supplemental or sensitivity analyses.

META-ANALYSIS 2: Meta-Analysis 2 will focus on the correlations between STEM and verbal ability stereotypes with three focal categories of STEM motivational outcomes: (a) confidence (e.g., expectancies for success, self-efficacy, perceived ability), (b) interests and values (e.g., intrinsic value, enjoyment, utility value), and (c) future educational and career plans (e.g., intended college major). We will convert bivariate correlation coefficients (e.g., Pearson’s r) into Fisher’s z-scores for meta-analytic models. 

If multiple regression coefficients are reported instead, we will send an author query for the bivariate correlations. Though we currently do not plan to include partial correlations or regression coefficients in our analyses, we may decide to include them if we would lose too many studies (e.g., more than half) if we excluded them. We plan to make this decision after coding studies, but before analyzing the data, so that our decision is based on data availability, but not the results. If we do include partial correlations (e.g., converted from regression coefficients), we would include a dummy code for them in all moderator analyses. In addition, we would conduct sensitivity analyses to examine if any results depend on including this other category of correlations.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Pages 19–24 of the uploaded protocol document detail our analytic plan for both meta-analyses, which we summarize below. 

MODELS: We will use mixed-effects meta-regression models to investigate how stereotypes and their correlation with STEM outcomes vary across child demographics, cultural contexts, and measures. These models, which will be estimated using restricted maximum likelihood, will assume that variation in effect sizes is due to fixed effects of moderators (e.g., age), random effects of residual between-study heterogeneity, and within-study sampling variance (Borenstein et al., 2009). Because many studies likely will generate multiple effect sizes, we will implement robust variance estimation (RVE) to account for effect size dependencies, using the small-sample correction based on the Satterthwaite approximation (Tipton, 2015) and the “CR2” bias-reduced linearization adjustment (Pustejovky & Tipton, 2018). We will first estimate mixed-effects meta-analysis model parameters using the rma.mv() function in the metafor R package (Viechtbauer, 2010) and then adjust the standard errors, degrees of freedom, and p values by implementing RVE using the coef_test() function in the clubSandwich package (Pustejovsky, 2018). 

META-ANALYSIS 1: Confirmatory moderator analyses will test our directional hypotheses such as pro-male STEM ability stereotypes should strengthen with age. We will examine each moderator in separate models and in one multivariable model that will simultaneously adjust for all confirmatory moderators. To control for nuisance methods variance, all models will include four dummy-coded covariates for the scale type: (a) 2 or 3 response options, (b) forced-choice scale with no gender-neutral response option for individual items, (c) continuous scale (vs. discrete ratings), and (d) separate ratings (vs. comparative scales). Though effect sizes will be standardized, the original measurement scale still could contribute additional variance that should be adjusted for. STEM ability and verbal ability stereotypes will be analyzed in separate statistical models, except when directing comparing their overall magnitude (in that case, both will be included in the same model to account for their correlation).

META-ANALYSIS 2: Our core prediction for Meta-Analysis 2 is that pro-male STEM and pro-male female ability stereotypes should relate to motivational STEM outcomes negatively for girls and positively for boys. We will test these basic predictions with four separate random-effects models for the four broad categories of correlations (see Table 9), along with characterizing their overall heterogeneity. Two additional mixed-effects models (bottom rows of Table 9) will directly examine average differences between boys’ and girls’ correlations by including one moderator for gender. For the correlations between girls’ STEM ability stereotypes and STEM motivational outcomes, we will conduct additional moderator analyses using mixed-effects models. We focus on this category of correlations in part because we expect to obtain the most primary data for it (relative to other categories).

SELECTIVE REPORTING BIAS ANALYSES: Though we will use several systematic search methods to find unpublished studies, our conclusions may nevertheless be subject to selective reporting bias (e.g., publication bias or outcome reporting bias). Researchers may be cautious to report results conflicting with commonly accepted theory and research hypotheses. As detailed in Appendix D in the uploaded protocol document, we will use three approaches as sensitivity analyses to diagnose and adjust for such biases: (a) selection modeling, (b) comparison of unpublished versus published studies, and (c) meta-regression to assess small-study effects. If the three approaches yield diverging conclusions, we will place the greatest weight on selection models for reasons detailed in Appendix D. Simulation studies have shown superior performance for selection models, compared to other publication bias methods, in several conditions that may likely characterize our meta-analysis such as moderate to large between-study heterogeneity (Carter, Schönbrodt, Gervais, & Hilgard, 2019).

attributes.title: Southern Scholarship Foundation Housing Initiative
attributes.description: Community organizations and colleges are searching for effective strategies to ensure that every student has a safe and secure place to live This project examines the influence of a scholarship to live rent-free in a cooperative living home offered by the Southern Scholarship Foundation to students at several colleges and universities in Florida.

q2.value: Sara Goldrick-Rab, Lara Perez-Felkner, Christine Baker-Smith

q3.value:
Scholarship on college access and success in higher education has taken for granted the role that basic needs, or the lack thereof, plays in shaping educational inequality. Basic needs – like stable housing – are essential for students to learn and flourish (Maslow, 1943). Moreover, recent research has highlighted the substantial challenges today’s students face in securing the most basic needs such as food and housing (Goldrick-Rab, Richardson, & Kinsley, 2017; Hallett, Crutchfield, & Maguire, 2019; Martinez, Frongillo, Leung, & Ritchie).
The Southern Scholarship Foundation (SSF) program aims to create an array of both qualitative and quantitative improvements in students’ lives. For example, students are given the opportunity to become part of a social network and community with housemates, which may affect their self-esteem, sense of belonging in college, and mental health. They are also relieved of a key source of financial pressure—rent—which has the potential to reduce their need to take on student debt or work long hours. Accepted applicants pay a semester food and utility bill averaging $900 and live in houses with approximately 10-30 students per house.
Each year, SSF receives about 25 times more applicants than it has spaces available in its houses, and when narrowed to qualified applicants, the ratio of applicants to spaces is about 3:1. This oversubscription provides an opportunity for randomization to examine the impact of the program through a randomized-control trial.
Under normal circumstances in which SSF selects participants, students receiving rent-free housing may have a higher or lower propensity to persist in college, even without the program. Those outcomes, in other words, may be predicted by their pre-existing characteristics that shaped program participation in the first place. We therefore propose an approach that introduces a selection process to cleanly distinguish non-participants from participants. Overall, our approach will be a mixed-methods research design involving a randomized experiment to examine the impact of SSF’s housing program on students.

q4.value:
The primary goal of the project is to measure the impact of the program on students’ near and long-term academic success.
1)	We hypothesize that the program will have a positive short-term impact on educational attainment, including course/credit completion, GPA and semester-to-semester retention as measured with administrative data. 
2)	We hypothesize the program will have a positive short-term impact on the effective use of financial aid, including FAFSA application and strategic use of loans.
3)	We hypothesize the program will have moderate term impacts on including reductions in food insecurity and financial stress, and improvements in housing quality and stability, measured in follow-up surveys.
4)	In addition, we hypothesize that a number of moderate-term outcomes will be positively impacted such as work behaviors, use of credit cards, use of advising and financial counseling services and recommended financial management practices, and students’ sense of belonging and satisfaction with the university (measured using follow-up surveys).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Researchers will assign treatment and control such that they fill open spaces at each of the scholarship houses each semester with “treatment” students. This number is expected to be 300 treated students and a corresponding number of controls by the completion of the project, but will vary each cycle depending on the number of open beds and total applicants.

Analysis. Given the variation in size between the smaller and larger housing blocks, with the largest being a 3-campus share in Tallahassee, FL (Florida State University, Tallahassee Community College, and Flagler College-Tallahassee), we will assess in descriptive and predictive models any block-specific patterns in student outcomes, albeit primarily for diagnostic purposes. With any block-specific patterns identified, we will use OLS regression analysis to examine the treatment impact on the dependent variables/outcomes while controlling for any unbalanced characteristics at each level according to What Works Clearinghouse (WWC) standards. Other variables described herein are expected to be more relevant predictors, moderators, and mediators of student outcomes.
The research team will use National Student Clearinghouse data to monitor student stop-out (when a student decides to take a break from higher education for at least one term) and transfer to another campus, as these data include enrollment outside of the participating institution. Students who have not graduated from participating institutions, are no longer enrolled, and do not appear in the Clearinghouse data will likely no longer be in college. In this case, attrition from the sample will indicate a negative outcome (i.e., failure to complete or persist in college). Some proximate outcomes, such as student grades, finances, and social-psychological well-being, will not be observable for some students who stop out (although we will attempt to survey all students, including those who have stopped out). For outcomes that could be affected by attrition, analyses will be approached with caution and, when necessary, bounds will be created based on assumptions about best- and worse-case scenarios for students who have stopped out. In these cases, appropriate caveats concerning potential biases due to attrition will accompany all estimates. 
Within-house spillover of the housing scholarship from treatment to control students is unlikely as the scholarship can be administered to only one student— it is not information that could be transferred and it cannot be shared. 
The contrast between conditions (our primary independent variable) will be as listed below. 
This independent variable of assignment to the housing scholarship is measured between-participant; we plan to control for and may also include fixed effects to capture institutional and gender blocks, as noted below. Given the size of the random assignment blocks, our hypothesized relationships focus on orthogonal relationships between the independent and dependent variables.

q9.value:
A research team member will work with SSF to conduct randomization after all applications have been received and ensure the integrity of the assignment. Baseline equivalence across treatment and control samples will be assessed based on WWC standards using Hedges’ G and Cohen’s kappa using observed variables provided on the scholarship applications and from the baseline survey. A second researcher will review these comparisons for quality assurance before randomized assignment is shared with SSF.
The research team will monitor implementation of treatment through regular communication with the administrators of the SSF scholarships. It is anticipated that most students offered the housing scholarship will accept it, however there are a variety of reasons why a student might not accept the treatment in this program – these students remain in the treatment group as per WWC guidance. Some of these reasons include changes in their intended institution that affect the scholarship availability (at either a different SSF campus or a campus that does not participate with SSF), a deferral in intended enrollment, or concerns about complying with house expectations. Students assigned treatment, whether they accept or not, will be assessed as treated students to the best of our ability based on available data though they will be identified in the data such that, if we find null effects, we can explore whether this was due to lack of take-up of the scholarship. Students who apply and are assigned to the waitlist condition can reapply indefinitely. Students who apply and are assigned to the control will not be permitted to reapply for at least two application cycles but will retain their control status in our analyses as per WWC standards.
Random assignment. Assignment is done within-institution and blocked by gender. Campuses that are geographically isolated (i.e., Florida Gulf Coast University) or have campus-specific housing stipulations (i.e., Florida A&M University) are blocked as single campus units, albeit broken out by gender given the single-sex design of SSF housing. For campuses that are geographically proximate, they share spaces within the housing block, an arrangement that predates the evaluation design. For example, the Gainesville, Florida location of both Santa Fe College (SFC) and University of Florida (UF) allow the campuses to share a SFC-UF housing block, for women and men interested in SSF housing for those campuses.
• Treatment condition. Student offered the housing scholarship after applying to receive the scholarship, after having been deemed eligible on the stated criteria: an Expected Family Contribution of no more than $7,500, a minimum 3.0 unweighted state GPA or 675 GED score, university acceptance at one of the seven university partners, and excellent character as deemed from the letters of recommendation as pertain to service in the community, work, and academics.
• Control condition. Student not offered the housing scholarship.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Data has been collected as part of the application cycle and baseline surveys that take place during the application period. These data have been examined for three reasons but have not been examined based on the analytic plan at this time.  Extant data have been examined by our data company, not the authors, to ensure 1) that students with suicidal ideations or other immediate needs are identified and provided additional supports 2) to ensure no issues with data collection or complications with assignment to treatment have taken place. The data company has worked directly with the service provider in these cases, researchers are notified of the issue but not the specific cases. Authors have examined application data to determine baseline equivalence and assist in the program provider with randomization.

question.value:
Students will be excluded from the study when they are not eligible for the application as per above. Data will be excluded from analysis based on WWC standards. Data will not be reported for groups smaller than 10 and outliers may receive special treatment by being excluded or having a flag in all analyses relevant to the outlying data.

Administrative data: Data will be collected from the application to the scholarship. During the evaluation period, the SSF application is amended to obtain consent from all applicants to participation in evaluation. Also, administrative data is collected from institutional representatives and NSC data for all participants will be secured for tracking academic outcomes.

Survey data: Surveys will be administered to all applicants to the program. Follow-up surveys at 6-12 months will be administered to all treatment and control students.
Data is collected from students via surveys at baseline and via an annual follow-up all students receive at least 6 months after receiving notice of the housing scholarship award and individual interviews of a stratified random sample of treatment and control students, in the semester following their intended enrollment into the scholarship houses or an alternative housing arrangement. Administrative data from NSC will be collected through 2021 to secure longitudinal outcomes of the scholarship, in addition to semi-annual administrative data updates from SSF regarding residential movement in and out of houses and acceptance of scholarship offers.

q13.value:
Current eligibility requirements would be maintained during the evaluation period. Therefore, all program participants will be “high-achieving students with financial need and good character” who are enrolled full-time at one of seven participating institutions (Flagler College - Tallahassee, Florida A&M University, Florida Gulf Coast University, Florida State University, Santa Fe College, Tallahassee Community College, and University of Florida) and maintain a 3.0 GPA. 
During the evaluation period, the pool of qualified applicants would be treated as follows for each cohort across up to 2 periods per year and 3 years total:
1.	The characteristics of the entire pool (an estimated 750 students per year) are examined for representation of desired attributes. SSF staff would then have the opportunity to use their desired factors to further narrow the pool to an appropriately diverse group, leaving approximately 2/3 of the pool remaining (~500 students).
2.	The diversified qualified applicant pool (the ~500 students per year) would then be sorted by college block (1-3 colleges depending on geographic region) and by gender given the single-sex housing design of SSF, and placed into a lottery, with participants (in the number equal to available spaces) selected at random. The result would be a group of participants (~150-200 per year) and diversified qualified applicant non-participants (~300-350 per year). 
3.	SSF would then place the chosen participants into houses, in groupings selected by staff as usual. Those housing assignments would be shared with evaluators. 

A small number of housing spaces could be held for participants who must be selected via a different process (due to the needs of funders, etc.)—those students will be flagged and withheld from the evaluation. In addition, the process described above could occur multiple times, if the period of application evaluation extends over many months.
This would result in a total program participation group (treatment) of about 300-400 students, and a total non-participant group of 300-400 students (control) plus an additional 200-300 non-treated students who comprise the housing waitlist. Such a sample size will make it possible to examine differential effects of the program for subgroups of students, such as analyses by race/ethnicity, college attended, etc.

q14.value: The student sample across these institutions in this project will total approximately 950 which should allow for identification of main impacts and facilitate the analysis of subgroup effects, though analyses of heterogeneous treatment impacts (differences among subgroups) will likely be underpowered and should be considered exploratory. The PowerUp! software was used for the analysis power calculations. All calculations assume 80% power and a 0.05 probability of Type I error (Dong & Maynard, 2013). Covariates are expected to account for 50% of variation in the outcome and 50% of the sample is expected to receive the housing scholarship. In the efficacy study, Southern Scholarship Foundation has committed to funding at least 300 scholarships over a 3-year period. With approximately 300 treated students, the power analysis indicates that pooling eight universities (of the nine that have indicated intent to participate) will yield sufficient power to detect an effect as small as a .333 MRES change in degree completion. The average effect sizes implied by the power analysis are reasonable for this intervention. While little data on the impacts of housing scholarships are available, and colleges do not publish graduation rates for near-completers, preliminary descriptive evidence from other studies, several led by Goldrick-Rab, pending publication is promising.

question.value:
The contrast between conditions (our primary independent variable) will be as listed below. 
This independent variable manipulated is assignment to the housing scholarship is measured between-participant; we plan to control for and may also include fixed effects to capture institutional and gender blocks, as noted below. Given the size of the random assignment blocks, our hypothesized relationships focus on orthogonal relationships between the independent and dependent variables.
Random assignment. Assignment is done within-institution and blocked by gender. Campuses that are geographically isolated (i.e., Florida Gulf Coast University) or have campus-specific housing stipulations (i.e., Florida A&M University) are blocked as single campus units, albeit broken out by gender given the single-sex design of SSF housing. For campuses that are geographically proximate, they share spaces within the housing block, an arrangement that predates the evaluation design. For example, the Gainesville, Florida location of both Santa Fe College (SFC) and University of Florida (UF) allow the campuses to share a SFC-UF housing block, for women and men interested in SSF housing for those campuses.
• Treatment condition. Student offered the housing scholarship after applying to receive the scholarship, after having been deemed eligible on the stated criteria: an Expected Family Contribution of no more than $7,500, a minimum 3.0 unweighted state GPA or 675 GED score, university acceptance at one of the seven university partners, and excellent character as deemed from the letters of recommendation as pertain to service in the community, work, and academics.
• Control condition. Student not offered the housing scholarship.

Primary, long-term, outcome: Degree completion. The primary goal of the project is to measure the impact of the housing scholarship on degree completion rates within 100% (4 years) and 150% (6 years) of when students began attending the university. Most students will have been enrolled for 0-1 years at the study’s inception but will remain enrolled in the housing scholarship program and postsecondary education for an additional 2-5 years depending on whether they are entering the study as a community college transfer, a second-year student, or a first time in college student. As described, the program will obtain graduation data from participating institutions and share with researchers. This data will be supplemented with National Student Clearinghouse information to better capture outcomes of transfer students. 
Near and Intermediate outcomes. In addition, a number of proximal outcomes of interest will include enrollment and persistence in subsequent terms, measured using administrative data (e.g., semester-to-semester retention, credits completed, and GPA), effective use of financial aid, including FAFSA application and strategic use of loans; reductions in food insecurity and financial stress, measured with surveys; and improvements in housing quality and stability, measured in follow-up surveys.

Some mediating and moderating variables such as financial stress or basic needs insecurity (food and housing) may be examined using an index. In these analyses we will follow the analytic process for creating index measures as described in the "Guide to assessing basic needs insecurity in higher education" (Sara Goldrick-Rab, Christine Baker-Smith, Vanessa Coca, and Elizabeth Looker 2019).

To identify institution-specific causal impacts of the housing scholarship, equation (1) will be estimated: (1) yi = α + β * Treatmenti + Xi + εi where yi represents an outcome for student i; Treatmenti is an indicator variable for whether a student was assigned to the treatment group; Xi is a vector of additional student-level covariates such as race, gender, family income, unmet need, etc. as available on the application; and εi is a term for student-specific random error. All analyses will account for student-level heterogeneity when computing standard errors, and house-specific fixed effects employed where appropriate. 
In Equation (1), β represents the treatment impact, the average improvement in outcome yi for the treatment group relative to the control group. If the housing scholarships are effective, estimates of β are expected to be positive, statistically significant, and substantively important. The impacts of the housing scholarship may be moderated by financial, academic, and demographic characteristics. For example, students with greater financial need, such as those with zero expected family contribution to college costs, may benefit more from the scholarship. To study whether these moderators are associated with heterogeneous impacts of the housing scholarship, an interaction between the relevant moderator and Treatmenti will be added to Equation (1). Substantively and statistically significant coefficients on these interaction terms will imply that the housing scholarship are more effective for students in those subgroups. 
Observations with missing data will be dropped from analyses for which their data are incomplete. For outcomes from administrative data (including National Student Clearinghouse data)—completion, persistence, financial aid, and academic achievement—few issues with missing data are anticipated. The research team will analyze survey data with caution, particularly if response rates are not balanced between treatment and control students. When necessary, estimates will be bounded with reasonable assumptions of best-case and worst-case scenario outcomes for students with missing data. In these cases, estimates will be accompanied by caveats concerning potential bias due to missing data. 
Although the experiment may lack sufficient power for a causal analysis of mediators, exploratory mediation analysis will provide evidence of correlations between the housing scholarship and hypothesized mediators. This work will indicate potential mechanisms for how the housing scholarship improve academic outcomes and suggest avenues for future research. For analysis of fidelity of implementation outcomes, researchers will examine treatment and control students’ presence in the scholarship houses as per house-records. These analyses will use simple counts and means and analysis of institutional communications, respectively. Additionally, exploratory analysis of survey results and in-person interviews will inform implementation analysis and any potential moderation implementation has on the impacts.

We will highlight results that show a statistical significance of p<0.05 as statistically significant and may also discuss results with p<0.10 as relevant to future study.

q24.value:
Moderators. Financial, academic, and demographic moderators may affect the relationship between the housing scholarship and academic success; they will be examined as outcomes above but also used as covariates or moderators in analyses of the primary outcome. Students with less unmet need might benefit more from receiving grants because the extra funds are more likely to fully resolve their financial challenges. However, the opposite may be true—if students with more unmet need benefit more from the program but are less likely to be included, it may not reduce equity gaps in outcomes. Similarly, the housing scholarship may have a greater impact on the outcomes of students who have demonstrated higher academic achievement before grant receipt, in the form of a higher GPA or more accumulated credits, who are more capable of meeting graduation requirements. In addition, high school grade point average (GPA) affects short- and longer-term outcomes, as a predictor of academic success in college and – more importantly for this study – as both an eligibility requirement for the housing scholarship and potentially as a moderator of access to merit aid scholarships for college (at different levels of support depending on academic performance) that may yield higher positive effects for students eligible for SSF and below the Bright Futures scholarship thresholds. 
To whom the housing scholarship should be targeted is of great interest to universities and philanthropic foundations offering support to college students. To maximize return on investment, they may seek to target supports to students with higher graduation probabilities. But this focus may not be cost-effective if those students would have graduated without the support. Analyses of impacts by predicted graduation probability can help institutions better target support to students whose graduation outcomes the intervention is most likely to improve. 
Mediators. An exploratory mediation analysis will examine associations between the housing scholarship and hypothesized mediators. Listed under intermediate outcomes above, several mediators might account for any relationship between the housing scholarship and distal outcomes. These mediators fall into two categories of proximal outcomes—financial and social-psychological. From a financial standpoint, the housing scholarship may reduce students’ unmet financial need, allowing them to use fewer loans or work less. These financial benefits, in turn, may result in enhanced focus on classwork, improved grades and credit completion, and completion and retention. Likewise, the housing scholarship may improve academic success through social-psychological outcomes. We will also investigate any potentially mediating effects of majoring in postsecondary STEM fields (25% of our year 1 sample), which may compete with students’ available time for paid work while studying and may negatively affect their college GPAs, with potential consequences for their merit aid renewal.
