registration_responses.q2: Sara Goldrick-Rab, Lara Perez-Felkner, Christine Baker-Smith
registration_responses.q3:
Scholarship on college access and success in higher education has taken for granted the role that basic needs, or the lack thereof, plays in shaping educational inequality. Basic needs – like stable housing – are essential for students to learn and flourish (Maslow, 1943). Moreover, recent research has highlighted the substantial challenges today’s students face in securing the most basic needs such as food and housing (Goldrick-Rab, Richardson, & Kinsley, 2017; Hallett, Crutchfield, & Maguire, 2019; Martinez, Frongillo, Leung, & Ritchie).
The Southern Scholarship Foundation (SSF) program aims to create an array of both qualitative and quantitative improvements in students’ lives. For example, students are given the opportunity to become part of a social network and community with housemates, which may affect their self-esteem, sense of belonging in college, and mental health. They are also relieved of a key source of financial pressure—rent—which has the potential to reduce their need to take on student debt or work long hours. Accepted applicants pay a semester food and utility bill averaging $900 and live in houses with approximately 10-30 students per house.
Each year, SSF receives about 25 times more applicants than it has spaces available in its houses, and when narrowed to qualified applicants, the ratio of applicants to spaces is about 3:1. This oversubscription provides an opportunity for randomization to examine the impact of the program through a randomized-control trial.
Under normal circumstances in which SSF selects participants, students receiving rent-free housing may have a higher or lower propensity to persist in college, even without the program. Those outcomes, in other words, may be predicted by their pre-existing characteristics that shaped program participation in the first place. We therefore propose an approach that introduces a selection process to cleanly distinguish non-participants from participants. Overall, our approach will be a mixed-methods research design involving a randomized experiment to examine the impact of SSF’s housing program on students.
registration_responses.q4:
The primary goal of the project is to measure the impact of the program on students’ near and long-term academic success.
1)	We hypothesize that the program will have a positive short-term impact on educational attainment, including course/credit completion, GPA and semester-to-semester retention as measured with administrative data. 
2)	We hypothesize the program will have a positive short-term impact on the effective use of financial aid, including FAFSA application and strategic use of loans.
3)	We hypothesize the program will have moderate term impacts on including reductions in food insecurity and financial stress, and improvements in housing quality and stability, measured in follow-up surveys.
4)	In addition, we hypothesize that a number of moderate-term outcomes will be positively impacted such as work behaviors, use of credit cards, use of advising and financial counseling services and recommended financial management practices, and students’ sense of belonging and satisfaction with the university (measured using follow-up surveys).

A research team member will work with SSF to conduct randomization after all applications have been received and ensure the integrity of the assignment. Baseline equivalence across treatment and control samples will be assessed based on WWC standards using Hedges’ G and Cohen’s kappa using observed variables provided on the scholarship applications and from the baseline survey. A second researcher will review these comparisons for quality assurance before randomized assignment is shared with SSF.
The research team will monitor implementation of treatment through regular communication with the administrators of the SSF scholarships. It is anticipated that most students offered the housing scholarship will accept it, however there are a variety of reasons why a student might not accept the treatment in this program – these students remain in the treatment group as per WWC guidance. Some of these reasons include changes in their intended institution that affect the scholarship availability (at either a different SSF campus or a campus that does not participate with SSF), a deferral in intended enrollment, or concerns about complying with house expectations. Students assigned treatment, whether they accept or not, will be assessed as treated students to the best of our ability based on available data though they will be identified in the data such that, if we find null effects, we can explore whether this was due to lack of take-up of the scholarship. Students who apply and are assigned to the waitlist condition can reapply indefinitely. Students who apply and are assigned to the control will not be permitted to reapply for at least two application cycles but will retain their control status in our analyses as per WWC standards.

registration_responses.q11: Data has been collected as part of the application cycle and baseline surveys that take place during the application period. These data have been examined for three reasons but have not been examined based on the analytic plan at this time.  Extant data have been examined by our data company, not the authors, to ensure 1) that students with suicidal ideations or other immediate needs are identified and provided additional supports 2) to ensure no issues with data collection or complications with assignment to treatment have taken place. The data company has worked directly with the service provider in these cases, researchers are notified of the issue but not the specific cases. registration_responses.q13:
Current eligibility requirements would be maintained during the evaluation period. Therefore, all program participants will be “high-achieving students with financial need and good character” who are enrolled full-time at one of seven participating institutions (Flagler College - Tallahassee, Florida A&M University, Florida Gulf Coast University, Florida State University, Santa Fe College, Tallahassee Community College, and University of Florida) and maintain a 3.0 GPA. 
During the evaluation period, the pool of qualified applicants would be treated as follows for each cohort across up to 2 periods per year and 3 years total:
1.	The characteristics of the entire pool (an estimated 750 students per year) are examined for representation of desired attributes. SSF staff would then have the opportunity to use their desired factors to further narrow the pool to an appropriately diverse group, leaving approximately 2/3 of the pool remaining (~500 students).
2.	The diversified qualified applicant pool (the ~500 students per year) would then be sorted by college block (1-3 colleges depending on geographic region) and by gender given the single-sex housing design of SSF, and placed into a lottery, with participants (in the number equal to available spaces) selected at random. The result would be a group of participants (~150-200 per year) and diversified qualified applicant non-participants (~300-350 per year). 
3.	SSF would then place the chosen participants into houses, in groupings selected by staff as usual. Those housing assignments would be shared with evaluators. 

A small number of housing spaces could be held for participants who must be selected via a different process (due to the needs of funders, etc.)—those students will be flagged and withheld from the evaluation. In addition, the process described above could occur multiple times, if the period of application evaluation extends over many months.
This would result in a total program participation group (treatment) of about 300-400 students, and a total non-participant group of 300-400 students (control) plus an additional 200-300 non-treated students who comprise the housing waitlist. Such a sample size will make it possible to examine differential effects of the program for subgroups of students, such as analyses by race/ethnicity, college attended, etc.
registration_responses.q14: The student sample across these institutions in this project will total approximately 950 which should allow for identification of main impacts and facilitate the analysis of subgroup effects, though analyses of heterogeneous treatment impacts (differences among subgroups) will likely be underpowered and should be considered exploratory. The PowerUp! software was used for the analysis power calculations. All calculations assume 80% power and a 0.05 probability of Type I error (Dong & Maynard, 2013). Covariates are expected to account for 50% of variation in the outcome and 50% of the sample is expected to receive the housing scholarship. In the efficacy study, Southern Scholarship Foundation has committed to funding at least 300 scholarships over a 3-year period. With approximately 300 treated students, the power analysis indicates that pooling eight universities (of the nine that have indicated intent to participate) will yield sufficient power to detect an effect as small as a .333 MRES change in degree completion. The average effect sizes implied by the power analysis are reasonable for this intervention. While little data on the impacts of housing scholarships are available, and colleges do not publish graduation rates for near-completers, preliminary descriptive evidence from other studies, several led by Goldrick-Rab, pending publication is promising.

registration_responses.q8.question:
Researchers will assign treatment and control such that they fill open spaces at each of the scholarship houses each semester with “treatment” students. This number is expected to be 300 treated students and a corresponding number of controls by the completion of the project, but will vary each cycle depending on the number of open beds and total applicants.

Analysis. Given the variation in size between the smaller and larger housing blocks, with the largest being a 3-campus share in Tallahassee, FL (Florida State University, Tallahassee Community College, and Flagler College-Tallahassee), we will assess in descriptive and predictive models any block-specific patterns in student outcomes, albeit primarily for diagnostic purposes. With any block-specific patterns identified, we will use OLS regression analysis to examine the treatment impact on the dependent variables/outcomes while controlling for any unbalanced characteristics at each level according to What Works Clearinghouse (WWC) standards. Other variables described herein are expected to be more relevant predictors, moderators, and mediators of student outcomes.
The research team will use National Student Clearinghouse data to monitor student stop-out (when a student decides to take a break from higher education for at least one term) and transfer to another campus, as these data include enrollment outside of the participating institution. Students who have not graduated from participating institutions, are no longer enrolled, and do not appear in the Clearinghouse data will likely no longer be in college. In this case, attrition from the sample will indicate a negative outcome (i.e., failure to complete or persist in college). Some proximate outcomes, such as student grades, finances, and social-psychological well-being, will not be observable for some students who stop out (although we will attempt to survey all students, including those who have stopped out). For outcomes that could be affected by attrition, analyses will be approached with caution and, when necessary, bounds will be created based on assumptions about best- and worse-case scenarios for students who have stopped out. In these cases, appropriate caveats concerning potential biases due to attrition will accompany all estimates. 
Within-house spillover of the housing scholarship from treatment to control students is unlikely as the scholarship can be administered to only one student— it is not information that could be transferred and it cannot be shared. 
The contrast between conditions (our primary independent variable) will be as listed below. 
This independent variable of assignment to the housing scholarship is measured between-participant; we plan to control for and may also include fixed effects to capture institutional and gender blocks, as noted below. Given the size of the random assignment blocks, our hypothesized relationships focus on orthogonal relationships between the independent and dependent variables.

Administrative data: Data will be collected from the application to the scholarship. During the evaluation period, the SSF application is amended to obtain consent from all applicants to participation in evaluation. Also, administrative data is collected from institutional representatives and NSC data for all participants will be secured for tracking academic outcomes.

Survey data: Surveys will be administered to all applicants to the program. Follow-up surveys at 6-12 months will be administered to all treatment and control students.
Data is collected from students via surveys at baseline and via an annual follow-up all students receive at least 6 months after receiving notice of the housing scholarship award and individual interviews of a stratified random sample of treatment and control students, in the semester following their intended enrollment into the scholarship houses or an alternative housing arrangement. Administrative data from NSC will be collected through 2021 to secure longitudinal outcomes of the scholarship, in addition to semi-annual administrative data updates from SSF regarding residential movement in and out of houses and acceptance of scholarship offers.

Campuses that are geographically isolated (i.e., Florida Gulf Coast University) or have campus-specific housing stipulations (i.e., Florida A&M University) are blocked as single campus units, albeit broken out by gender given the single-sex design of SSF housing. For campuses that are geographically proximate, they share spaces within the housing block, an arrangement that predates the evaluation design. For example, the Gainesville, Florida location of both Santa Fe College (SFC) and University of Florida (UF) allow the campuses to share a SFC-UF housing block, for women and men interested in SSF housing for those campuses.
• Treatment condition. Student offered the housing scholarship after applying to receive the scholarship, after having been deemed eligible on the stated criteria: an Expected Family Contribution of no more than $7,500, a minimum 3.0 unweighted state GPA or 675 GED score, university acceptance at one of the seven university partners, and excellent character as deemed from the letters of recommendation as pertain to service in the community, work, and academics.
• Control condition. Student not offered the housing scholarship.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Primary, long-term, outcome: Degree completion. The primary goal of the project is to measure the impact of the housing scholarship on degree completion rates within 100% (4 years) and 150% (6 years) of when students began attending the university. Most students will have been enrolled for 0-1 years at the study’s inception but will remain enrolled in the housing scholarship program and postsecondary education for an additional 2-5 years depending on whether they are entering the study as a community college transfer, a second-year student, or a first time in college student. As described, the program will obtain graduation data from participating institutions and share with researchers. This data will be supplemented with National Student Clearinghouse information to better capture outcomes of transfer students. 
Near and Intermediate outcomes. In addition, a number of proximal outcomes of interest will include enrollment and persistence in subsequent terms, measured using administrative data (e.g., semester-to-semester retention, credits completed, and GPA), effective use of financial aid, including FAFSA application and strategic use of loans; reductions in food insecurity and financial stress, measured with surveys; and improvements in housing quality and stability, measured in follow-up surveys.
registration_responses.q18.question: Some mediating and moderating variables such as financial stress or basic needs insecurity (food and housing) may be examined using an index. In these analyses we will follow the analytic process for creating index measures as described in the "Guide to assessing basic needs insecurity in higher education" (Sara Goldrick-Rab, Christine Baker-Smith, Vanessa Coca, and Elizabeth Looker 2019).
registration_responses.q19.question:
To identify institution-specific causal impacts of the housing scholarship, equation (1) will be estimated: (1) yi = α + β * Treatmenti + Xi + εi where yi represents an outcome for student i; Treatmenti is an indicator variable for whether a student was assigned to the treatment group; Xi is a vector of additional student-level covariates such as race, gender, family income, unmet need, etc. as available on the application; and εi is a term for student-specific random error. All analyses will account for student-level heterogeneity when computing standard errors, and house-specific fixed effects employed where appropriate. 
In Equation (1), β represents the treatment impact, the average improvement in outcome yi for the treatment group relative to the control group. If the housing scholarships are effective, estimates of β are expected to be positive, statistically significant, and substantively important. The impacts of the housing scholarship may be moderated by financial, academic, and demographic characteristics. For example, students with greater financial need, such as those with zero expected family contribution to college costs, may benefit more from the scholarship. To study whether these moderators are associated with heterogeneous impacts of the housing scholarship, an interaction between the relevant moderator and Treatmenti will be added to Equation (1). Substantively and statistically significant coefficients on these interaction terms will imply that the housing scholarship are more effective for students in those subgroups. 
Observations with missing data will be dropped from analyses for which their data are incomplete. For outcomes from administrative data (including National Student Clearinghouse data)—completion, persistence, financial aid, and academic achievement—few issues with missing data are anticipated. The research team will analyze survey data with caution, particularly if response rates are not balanced between treatment and control students. When necessary, estimates will be bounded with reasonable assumptions of best-case and worst-case scenario outcomes for students with missing data. In these cases, estimates will be accompanied by caveats concerning potential bias due to missing data. 
Although the experiment may lack sufficient power for a causal analysis of mediators, exploratory mediation analysis will provide evidence of correlations between the housing scholarship and hypothesized mediators. This work will indicate potential mechanisms for how the housing scholarship improve academic outcomes and suggest avenues for future research. For analysis of fidelity of implementation outcomes, researchers will examine treatment and control students’ presence in the scholarship houses as per house-records. These analyses will use simple counts and means and analysis of institutional communications, respectively. Additionally, exploratory analysis of survey results and in-person interviews will inform implementation analysis and any potential moderation implementation has on the impacts.

attributes.title: Protocol for a scoping review of mHealth research and implementation in older adults with asthma and COPD
attributes.description: A scoping review of quantitiative and qualitative mHealth research in asthma and COPD to determine if and how older adults have been included and considered in the mHealth research cycle.

summary.value:
Protocol for a scoping review of mHealth research and implementation in older adults with asthma and COPD

INTRODUCTION 
Rationale. 
In Canada, 91% of adults use the Internet regularly and 76% own a smartphone.[1] Consequently, mobile Internet-enabled devices like smartphones and tablets are increasingly being incorporated into the delivery of healthcare.  These technologies and applications, referred to as “mHealth”, can be leveraged for health data collection, health monitoring, patient education, behaviour change promotion, and enhancing communication between patients and physicians.[2] 
One area in which mHealth solutions have significant potential is the evolving healthcare needs of aging populations. mHealth can provide older adults with medication assistance, and improve disease self-management, monitoring, and patient education.[3–5] Though this area of mHealth is still developing and rigorous clinical evidence is sparse, a scoping review in 2017 of smart device-based mHealth interventions for older adults identified several studies that found mHealth-related improvements in diabetes control, weight retention in patients post-gastrectomy for gastric cancer, and quality of life in patients heart failure.[6] However, there are also important barriers to successfully delivering these technologies to adults 65 years and older,[4] who represent 17.2% of the Canadian population,[7] and account for 45% of national public healthcare expenditure.[8] Access is one obstacle, as daily Internet use and smartphone ownership remain disproportionately lower in older adults despite significant increases in the past 5 years.[1] Usability concerns are another barrier, as functional limitations and age-related challenges are not often considered during mHealth development,[4] and applications developed for a general populations are frequently not suitable for older adult users.[9] Accordingly, a recent scoping review of mHealth for older adults found that despite user interest in older populations, acceptance and engagement with mHealth was “low and inconsistent”.[5]
Asthma and COPD are two examples of highly prevalent airways diseases in which there is a growing interest in the use of mHealth.[10–12] mHealth interventions are particularly well suited to the management of airways diseases, as they can help facilitate the patient self-monitoring and self-management that are integral to effective care in asthma and COPD.[10,11,13] These two diseases are also growing in relevance in older populations, as asthma and COPD prevalence are increasing in older adults in Canada as the population ages,[14,15] and older populations with asthma and COPD have been shown to have disproportionately worse respiratory health outcomes compared to younger patients.[16–19] However, little is currently known about the effectiveness and acceptance of airways disease mHealth tools,  specifically in older adult populations, nor how older adults have been incorporated into asthma and COPD mHealth research cycles.[5,11,12,20–22] Given this lack of knowledge, a scoping review is an appropriate initial strategy to explore these questions, as it can be used to “examine broad areas to identify gaps in the evidence, clarify key concepts, and report on the types of evidence that address and inform practice”.[23] A scoping review will help to contextualize the current state of knowledge related to mHealth use and development in older patients with asthma and COPD, and will guide future study in this evolving field. 

Objectives. 
To comprehensively review mobile health research in adult patients with asthma and COPD in order to:
1) Examine age-based inclusion/exclusion criteria applied in primary studies of mHealth interventions as well as the proportion of recruited adults aged 65 years or older
2) Identify any reported mHealth implementation strategies and/or effectiveness outcomes that addressed patient age or are stratified by patient age.
3) Determine if and how older adults were included and specifically considered in the development process for each identified mHealth intervention

This protocol was developed using the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-analysis Scoping Review Checklist (PRISMA-ScR),[24] the Joanna Briggs Institute Reviewer Manual for scoping reviews,[25] and revised by team members.  

METHODS
Eligibility Criteria. 
Studies of interest will be those that report on the clinical evaluation of an mHealth tool targeting the management of any airways disease in adult patients, in primary or specialized care.  Acceptable study designs will include randomized controlled trials, retrospective or prospective observational studies, quasi-experimental designs (i.e. controlled before-and-after studies, interrupted time series analysis), and qualitative studies.  We will include studies which:  1) recruited adult patients; 2) targeted asthma or COPD; 3) were published after 2010 (this is consistent with other mHealth reviews and represents the time at which smartphones and tablets became widely adopted in North America);[6] 4) study an mHealth intervention as defined by the World Health Organization,[26] and 5) were published in English or French.  Studies in which the mHealth intervention is only a short message service (i.e. text-message or SMS) will be excluded, as this represents a limited and traditional definition of mHealth that doesn’t capture the complexity of mHealth applications using the full feature set of smart-devices available today, such as applications and interactive touch screens.[6] As such, age-related issues with SMS-only mHealth are unlikely to fully encompass those that may arise with more complex modern mHealth applications.

Information sources. 
An experienced information scientist will complete the search and a second will independently appraise it using the PRESS checklist.[27] The search strategy will begin by identifying important keywords through a limited search of highly relevant articles in eHealth journals, and these keywords will then be used to search Ovid MEDLINE, EMBASE and the Cochrane Central Registry of Controlled Trials for relevant research published after January 1st, 2010.  Following this, reference lists of included articles will also be searched for further relevant research reports. The grey literature will also be searched using both Google Scholar as well as the Canadian Agency for Drugs and Technologies in Health (CADTH) practical grey literature searching tool.[28] The search may be revised iteratively to include new important search terms as the reviewers become more familiar with the field. The initial search will begin in April 2020.

Selection of Sources of Evidence. 
Two reviewers will assess studies independently for inclusion in the scoping review and perform data abstraction.  Screening will begin with titles and abstracts, and then proceed to full text review.  At each stage, the two reviewers will perform a calibration exercise using a random sample of references (50 for abstract and title screening, and 25 for full text screening), identifying the level of agreement for inclusion/exclusion decisions, and discussing any disagreements.  Once a level of agreement >80% has been achieved, the remaining references will be screened.[29] Following screening, data abstraction will be performed. A calibration exercise on 5 randomly selected included studies will be performed as detailed above prior to full abstraction. Among the mHealth intervention studies, information regarding the study population (geographic location, demographic descriptors, age distribution, disease-related descriptors, and any inclusion of caregivers/family members), study methodology (study design type and setting), and the intervention (type of mHealth technology [i.e. mobile phone, tablet, smartwatch], nature of mHealth intervention [detailed description], target user outcomes [i.e. uptake, knowledge, behaviour], and any effort to address older age in implementation strategies) will be extracted. A priori inclusion/exclusion criteria for age as well any age-based recruitment quotas will be extracted.  Any reporting of study outcomes stratified by age will be extracted.  Following this, studies will be reviewed for any reference to publication(s) describing the original development of the mHealth tool, and identified reports will be retrieved and reviewed to extract information regarding the age distribution of patients involved in tool development (if any), details regarding the methods used in tool development (i.e. usability testing, qualitative methods, etc.), and any mention of age-related development considerations.  In studies without reference to relevant mHealth development work, study authors (first and last) will be contacted by email (2 attempts, 1 week apart) to inquire about development processes using a standardized questionnaire.

Data Charting Process. 
A data-charting form will be jointly developed by the two reviewers and discussed with the research supervisor. Two reviewers will independently chart the data, discussing the results and any disagreements.  Data charting will be iteratively updated based on these discussions. Specifically, the proportion of mHealth intervention studies including adults 65 years and older will be presented, stratifying by study methodology, inclusion/exclusion criteria description, and disease type.  Next, any outcomes stratified by age will be presented.  Finally, the age distributions and methodologies in accompanying development studies will be similarly charted.  

Registration and reporting. 
This protocol will be registered online in Open Science Framework.  Study methods and results will be reported using PRISMA-ScR checklist.[24]

Potential Limitations. 	
While a scoping review will help to identify the existing body of literature pertaining to mHealth research in older adults with airways disease, one important limitation of this type of review strategy is that it is not designed to assess the methodological quality of identified research.[30] As this research area further develops over time, a systematic review strategy would be warranted to assess the quality of available research. Additionally, only works published in English and French, and after 2010 will be searched. Though this might exclude some early mHealth research, 2010 is a commonly used cut-off in contemporaneous mHealth research, as this is the date by which smartphone and tablet use was considered to be widely adopted across North America.[6]

Potential outputs. 
This scoping review will comprehensively map the current state of mHealth research in airways disease at it pertains to the inclusion and consideration of older adults.  Based on our initial literature review, we are likely to find that in asthma mHealth, few studies include an asthma-population representative proportion of adults 65 years and older.  In COPD, older adults will make up a much larger proportion of implementation study participants, but their perspectives and needs may not often be specifically considered during development research.  When present, the methods used to specifically include the input of older adults in mHealth development are likely to vary, from referencing work done in other tools, to formal usability testing, to qualitative inquiry. These results will help to further contextualize the existing evidence gaps identified in our literature review and will guide future efforts to study, and ultimately to improve upon airways disease mHealth tools.
